description.narrative: The project Youth led capacity building and campaign on gender and resilience (GAR) aims to enhance the capacity of youths and students on GAR considering Gendered Crunch Model (GCM) and the Sendai Framework (SF) to mobilize local communities, particularly women. As Women and girls in Bangladesh are disproportionally impacted by disasters and  women’s contributions to disaster risk reduction are often overlooked, the current project will build capacity of youth girls and boys in managing risks in a gender-responsive manner. The project tends to achieve three specific objectives 1.  Enhance competence of youths to facilitate GAR. 2. Strengthen community resilient strategies according to GCM and SF Priority-1 & Priority-4 and 3. Promote institutionalization of woman’s leadership on GAR with special focus on access to government and non-government institutions, CSOs. The expected results are a. Enhanced capacity of the 200 youths to deal with GAR. Indicators: At least 80% youths can identify alternative way of diversifications of livelihoods. At least 80% of youths relating the Gender and Resilience-GAR issues to instances from one’s own life. b. Enhanced capacity of the community to combat climate induced disaster. Indicators: Facilitate monthly discussions in community meetings with local authorities, Disaster Management Committee at Union/Upazila level to share and strengthen to access to information. Youths facilitate to involving women in development of community resilience plans to combat climate induced disaster.; c. Increased access of the vulnerable communities to government and non-government Services. Indicators: At least 50% of community people have access to land and disaster information, Local Government Engineering Department (LGED), Department of Agriculture, Fisheries, Forestry, Livestock, Health & Nutrition, Local Elected Bodies (LEBs), livelihood opportunities through access to credit or skills building and training activities. Support local government to develop gender sensitive resilience strategy to combat climate induced disaster. Main rights holders including stakeholders are 200 youths (70% men, 30% women), 3000 local  (70% women, 30% men) communities, 100 people with disability (50% women), 300 indigenous people (70% women, 30% men), 60 marginal groups (50% women, 50% men).Other stakeholders are journalists, local elected bodies and government departments. This project will be implemented in Shyamnagar sub-district (12 Unions) in Satkhira district and Kalmakanda sub-district (3 Unions) in Netrakona district.
This project mainly contributes to results within Sustainable development and climate justice. Results will be reported later in the Global Civsam grant period 2016-2020
